Award.AwardTitle: ICN-WEN: Collaborative Research: ICN-Enabled Secure Edge Networking with Augmented Reality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technological advances have moved society into an exciting era of mobile computing. Our daily lives can be further enriched by a new generation of mobile applications, such as augmented reality (AR) which broadens one's real-world perception by harmonizing sound, image, video, and sensors from multiple sources to aid comprehension and navigation. However, today's Internet operates with the address-based TCP/IP protocol architecture developed 40 years ago, which greatly limits the full promises of these new applications. Thus, current AR implementations face challenges in performance, scalability and availability upon disasters. This proposed research project (ICE-AR) aims to develop a new wireless network architecture to address these limitations and provide pervasive support for these emerging applications.

The ICE-AR project team will apply and extend six years of research efforts on Named Data Networking (NDN), a realization of the Information Centric Networking (ICN) vision, to create this new architecture. The design emphasizes application-level data naming, data-centric security and computing, asynchronous publishing and consumption, and efficient use of local and proximate resources. The architecture will unify latest advances in wireless communication with domain-specific computing technologies to accelerate AR at the wireless edge and deliver robust performance, with or without the pre-deployed infrastructure support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technological advances in computing and networking have moved society into an exciting edge computing era, where people’s daily life can be enhanced by new applications of ever increasing sophistication. In this project, we aimed to add to the research contributions from the Named Data Networking project, a realization of the Information Centric Networking (ICN) vision, to develop a new wireless edge computing architecture that can seamlessly integrate networking, computation, storage, and security into a cohesively communicating and yet highly distributed ecosystem. 

Intellectual Merit: In the security dimension, which was co-led by New Mexico State University, the contributions included: design and implementation of a solution for using location-based certificates in mobile data publication; design and implementation of attribute based signatures (ABS) for data authentication that eliminates the need to retrieve individual certificates, and created the first implementation for attribute-based security (ABS); presented a framework to mitigate denial of service attacks due to interest flooding in the network; enhanced the proposed NDN architecture for meeting the needs of the diverse applications in the future smart grid—a critical infrastructure. 

Broader Impact: The ICE-AR project offered a great opportunity to train a new generation of researchers and engineers who can solve problems across the borders, and at the intersection of multiple areas: application development, wireless networking, security, and high performance computation. At NMSU, the project has helped provide opportunities to two Hispanic students with one completing his MS degree and joining White Sands Missile Range and the other working on completing his MS, with interest to pursue a PhD degree. The project has also support two other domestic students one undergraduate student and the other an MS student, who have graduated to join the Sandia National Laboratories and Mitre Corporation, respectively. The research results will also help in securing networks of the future and the privacy and confidentiality of the users of these networks.
